physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Manager, Lloyd’s Bank 67 Kingsway London W.C.2 England. Unsigned. Includes a postscript with royalties for Some Imagist Poets.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Thank you very much for your letter about "Fir-Flower Tablets." It was splendid to get. The book seems to be making friends. Even Arthur Waley, who is not, I think, inclined to be very agreeable to other translators calls it "an admirable book."

I wonder how your "Hymen" is doing. I reviewed it for the "Post." I wonder if you saw the review. If you did not, I shall be very glad to send you a copy. I saw a ridiculously ignorant one of it in the "London Spectator" and a superb one by May Sinclair in the "Dial."

I am delighted that you are included in the "Miscellany" this year. You should have been in the first one. I have not seen your contributions, but Louis Untermeyer tells me they are very fine. From those contributions to the book which I have seen (I have not seen those of all the poets), I should say that it is going to be a better volume than the last one.

Meanwhile I peg away at my book on Keats and, although I find it interesting, I cuss and swear at ever having undertaken such an enormous task. On the whole, I think Keats was more interesting as a man with potentialities than as a finished poet, although certain of his things still delight me – rather lines and expressions than whole poems, however. He ought to have lived in our age; I think he agreed with it a great deal in his point of view. Of course, when I say that in print, everybody will come out with a howl and say I am writing propaganda again; but that will not be true, so I need not care. I have found enough new material to make the book worth doing, I think.

I am just starting off on another lecture trip which will carry me to Charleston. It should be lovely there. I was there once sixteen years ago. There is a beautiful old place there laid out by Michaud, a famous landscape gardener, in the eighteenth century. The place is abandoned, has been, I think, since the Civil War, but the grounds remain all laid out with azaleas and paths running between them, and the azaleas are as high as small trees, and their blossoms drop on paths, and you walk softly upon the colours of the rainbow. How you would delight in it!

I am very much worried about Winifred’s poems which she sent me. They cannot be used, Hilda, it is impossible. They have that curious malodorous touch which permeates the freak poetry that the "Little Review" likes. She did better when she followed you and me. Robert McAlmon is not a good model for her. I have not dared write to her for some time because I hate to tell her that nothing can be done with the book, but it cannot be. If it is published it will simply hurt her, and it will not be published by any reputable firm. What a child of phases she is, and how important, therefore, that the influences surrounding her should be the right ones! I do not suppose that either you or I can do anything about it. Husbands take precedence over friends even when the friends are past literary flames. I woke her up, you pointed her to beautiful perfection, and Robert McAlmon is engaged in toppling her over. I wonder what the next phase will be. She seems greatly enamoured of sexual problems at present, which is, I suppose, partly the trend of our most youthful youth of to-day, and partly the effect of marriage. Poor little girl; where will it end.
Well, I must stop this letter as I have a hundred things to do and I am leaving on Monday. Write again soon. Mrs. Russell joins me in much love, and please remember us both to your mother.
body.postscript: P.S. Oh, the draft!
